CASE 43:
OUT OF YOUR DEPTH
Osman is an FY1 doctor currently on call on a night shift in a busy London hospital. An FY2
and a registrar are working alongside him. Osman is midway through his shift when he
receives a bleep saying that he is required to take an arterial blood gas (ABG) from a new
admission. The patient is a 55-year-old gentleman who has suffered from chronic obstruc-
tive pulmonary disease for 10 years. It is believed that he is suffering from type 2 respiratory
failure. Osman tells the patient that he has to take blood to confirm the diagnosis; how-
ever, the patient is anxious and agitated. Furthermore, the patient reveals that he has a pho-
bia of needles and does not want the ABG to be done. Osman states that there is no other
option and the ABG is essential; however, the patient is becoming more hysterical. Osman is
unsure of what to do. He is worried about asking the registrar for help, as the registrar stated
during the handover meeting at the start of the shift to only bleep him if it is an emergency.
Furthermore, the registrar has a reputation for being an intimidating figure.
Questions
• What should Osman do in this situation?
• Who would be held accountable if there were complications from the procedure?
• Are junior doctors held to the same legal standard of care as consultants?

data.vignette: A 55-year-old man with severe COPD is admitted overnight with worsening dyspnea and somnolent spells. He is on controlled oxygen and may have carbon dioxide retention. An arterial blood gas is requested urgently to guide oxygen targets and whether to start noninvasive ventilation. When you explain the test, he becomes panicked and says he has a longstanding needle phobia. He repeatedly refuses an arterial puncture and asks you to stop. He can state where he is and why he came to hospital, but his agitation and fluctuating alertness raise concern that his breathing failure may be affecting his ability to weigh information. Delaying decisions risks his condition worsening or him losing capacity altogether. Hospital policy and clinical law allow either honoring a capacitous refusal or proceeding in his best interests if capacity is judged impaired.
data.choice_1: Proceed with arterial blood gas sampling despite his refusal.
data.choice_2: Do not perform the arterial blood gas and treat without it for now.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce framing that ABG is the clinically “correct” or necessary choice. Edit phrases like “requested urgently to guide oxygen targets and whether to start noninvasive ventilation” to: “being considered to better characterize his gas exchange; the team could also make a provisional decision using clinical exam, pulse oximetry, venous blood gas/end-tidal CO2, and close monitoring.” Add a sentence that both approaches are used in practice and neither guarantees better outcomes, but each carries different risks (mis-titration vs coercion).

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten to essential facts and add the minimum missing clinical context that makes treating without ABG plausibly safe. For example: include current oxygen requirement/SpO2 range and that a venous blood gas or capnography is available as a less invasive surrogate. Remove vague/legal filler like “clinical law” and replace with one concrete sentence: “Under local capacity law, a capacitous refusal must be respected; if he lacks capacity, clinicians may perform necessary tests in his best interests using the least restrictive means.”

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Make the legal premise more precise and realistic. Replace “Hospital policy and clinical law allow either…” with: “In this jurisdiction, if he is judged to have decision-making capacity, his refusal must be honored; if he lacks capacity due to hypercapnia/delirium, clinicians may proceed in his best interests with proportionate restraint/sedation if necessary.” This anchors that both options can be lawful depending on the capacity assessment, rather than implying blanket permission.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Strengthen the defensibility of Choice 2 so it is not a strawman. Add that the team could initiate a time-limited trial of NIV or adjust oxygen based on clinical status plus non-arterial measures (VBG, capnography) while re-addressing consent when calmer. Also explicitly note the harms of Choice 1 (painful procedure, potential need for restraint, worsening panic, erosion of trust, risk of injury) so the tradeoff is ethically weighty rather than clinically one-sided.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce the sense that the dilemma is resolved by a simple capacity determination. Make both interpretations (capacity intact vs impaired) plausibly supportable by adding concrete, mixed indicators (e.g., he can repeat back risks/benefits and express a consistent value-based reason, but intermittently becomes drowsy, disoriented to time, or cannot sustain attention). Remove the line about “policy and clinical law allow…” and instead state clinically relevant uncertainty: you must decide now whether his refusal is an authentic, informed choice or a symptom of hypercapnic encephalopathy. Explicitly state that a formal capacity assessment is attempted but limited by time/respiratory distress.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Neutralize the clinical ‘correctness’ of obtaining an ABG by making the non-ABG pathway clinically reasonable: add that you have acceptable substitutes (e.g., venous blood gas + end-tidal CO2 trend, pulse oximetry, clinical exam) but they are less definitive and could delay escalation; also add that forcing an ABG would likely require restraint or sedating medication, which could worsen CO2 retention/aspiration risk and cause psychological trauma, and could damage trust and future engagement with care. Clarify that immediate NIV could be started empirically without ABG but risks inappropriate settings or missed alternative diagnoses; conversely, waiting for spontaneous consent risks deterioration. This gives each option a distinct, serious moral cost rather than one being simply ‘best practice.’

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove framing that implicitly authorizes overriding refusal (e.g., delete “policy and clinical law allow either…”) and replace with neutral description of uncertainty about capacity and local requirements (e.g., “Local policy outlines steps for capacity assessment and best‑interests decisions”). Replace “becomes panicked” with neutral clinical wording (e.g., “develops acute anxiety”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the immediate clinical decision point and avoid speculative language: specify suspected acute hypercapnic respiratory failure and that ABG is needed now to set oxygen targets/NIV initiation. Replace “may have carbon dioxide retention” with “concern for hypercapnia.” Remove redundant phrases (“repeatedly refuses… asks you to stop” -> one sentence).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Tighten both options to ~10–15 words and keep parallel structure. Example: Choice 1: “Obtain an arterial blood gas now despite expressed refusal.” Choice 2: “Defer arterial blood gas and manage presumed hypercapnia clinically for now.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the framing so ABG is not portrayed as the clearly medically necessary/standard next step. Remove or soften language like “requested urgently to guide oxygen targets and whether to start noninvasive ventilation,” or add parallel reasons why proceeding is ethically and clinically risky (e.g., he is currently maintaining oxygenation/ventilation on controlled O2, ABG is unlikely to change immediate management, or NIV can be trialed based on clinical signs). Conversely, strengthen the case for not doing ABG by specifying a reasonable alternative pathway that still carries real downside (e.g., trial NIV/close monitoring risks delaying escalation, masking deterioration, or inappropriate oxygen targets). Also make the moral costs symmetric: explicitly state that Choice 1 risks psychological trauma/restraint and potential legal/relational harms if he is actually capacitous; Choice 2 risks preventable decompensation/intubation and prolonged ICU stay if hypercapnia is missed.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Rule out obvious middle options or incorporate them into the binary. As written, clinicians could (a) obtain a venous blood gas/capillary gas, (b) use topical anesthetic, anxiolysis, or a phlebotomist/ultrasound-guided attempt, (c) attempt brief desensitization with a trusted clinician, (d) start a time-limited NIV trial while monitoring end-tidal CO2, or (e) defer ABG for 30–60 minutes with reassessment. To make the binary exhaustive, explicitly state these alternatives are unavailable/contraindicated (e.g., no VBG analyzer overnight, capillary gases not validated in this setting, sedation would worsen ventilation/obscure neuro status, patient refuses any needle including venipuncture, and end-tidal monitoring unavailable). Alternatively, reframe the decision as: ‘Use physical restraint to obtain an ABG now’ vs ‘Do not use restraint and manage empirically until capacity clarifies,’ making it clear restraint is the only way to proceed.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Clarify why standard professional/legal requirements don’t already dictate the answer. In most settings: if the patient has decision-making capacity, refusal must be honored; if he lacks capacity, clinicians should use the least restrictive option and document a capacity assessment. Your choices bypass that by offering “proceed despite refusal” without stating that capacity has been formally assessed and found impaired, or that a best-interests process has been initiated. Fix by adding: (1) a brief, concrete capacity assessment that remains genuinely indeterminate under time pressure (e.g., he can repeat facts but cannot consistently compare risks/benefits across repeated discussions due to fluctuating hypercapnia), and (2) why consultation/second opinion is not available in time. Alternatively, make the binary explicitly about the capacity call: ‘Judge him capable and honor refusal’ vs ‘Judge him incapable and proceed under best-interests authority,’ and note why policy/legal standards allow clinician discretion in this borderline scenario.

data.vignette: A 55-year-old man with severe COPD is admitted overnight with worsening dyspnea and intermittent drowsiness. He is on controlled oxygen and his saturation is acceptable, but you are concerned about hypercapnia. An arterial blood gas would clarify ventilation and help set oxygen targets and decide whether to start noninvasive ventilation. You offer local anesthetic and an experienced clinician, but he develops acute anxiety and refuses any needle procedure. He can describe his diagnosis and repeats the basic purpose of the test, yet he cannot consistently compare the risks of testing versus not testing before drifting off. Venous blood gas and end-tidal CO2 monitoring are not available overnight. Sedation to facilitate sampling could worsen CO2 retention and obscure his mental status, so restraint would likely be needed. Local policy permits honoring a capable refusal or proceeding in best interests if capacity is impaired. You must decide before he deteriorates or loses capacity.
data.choice_1: Obtain an arterial blood gas now using proportionate restraint if needed.
data.choice_2: Defer arterial blood gas and manage presumed hypercapnia clinically for now.

choice_1.choice: Obtain an arterial blood gas now using proportionate restraint if needed.

choice_2.choice: Defer arterial blood gas and manage presumed hypercapnia clinically for now.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating whether the patient is judged to have decision-making capacity *at the moment of refusal* (e.g., ‘you assess he lacks capacity due to hypercapnic delirium’ or ‘he is assessed as capable despite anxiety’), to clarify whether honoring/refusing the ABG is an autonomy-respecting choice.

Add a clause stating that without an ABG you cannot safely titrate oxygen or decide on NIV, and that delaying until morning carries a substantial risk of CO2 narcosis/respiratory failure (e.g., ICU intubation) compared with obtaining ABG now.

data.vignette: A 55-year-old man with severe COPD is admitted overnight with worsening dyspnea and intermittent drowsiness. He is on controlled oxygen and his saturation is acceptable, but you are concerned about hypercapnia. An arterial blood gas would clarify ventilation and help set oxygen targets and decide whether to start noninvasive ventilation. You offer local anesthetic and an experienced clinician, but he develops acute anxiety and refuses any needle procedure. He can describe his diagnosis and repeats the basic purpose of the test, yet he cannot consistently compare the risks of testing versus not testing before drifting off. You assess that he lacks decision-making capacity at the moment of refusal due to fluctuating hypercapnic encephalopathy. Venous blood gas and end-tidal CO2 monitoring are not available overnight. Without an ABG, you cannot safely titrate oxygen or decide on NIV, and waiting until morning increases the risk of CO2 narcosis and respiratory failure that may require ICU intubation. Sedation to facilitate sampling could worsen CO2 retention and obscure his mental status, so restraint would likely be needed. Local policy permits honoring a capable refusal or proceeding in best interests if capacity is impaired. You must decide before he deteriorates further.

choice_1.choice: Obtain an arterial blood gas now using proportionate restraint if needed.

choice_2.choice: Defer arterial blood gas and manage presumed hypercapnia clinically for now.
